job_title: forklift driver (receiving) in Fall River, MA
pros:
I worked as an ordinary forklift driver. Receiving side of the warehouse.

The pay wasn't great. But if you take advantage of the benefits package, its fair.

They also are flexible about accommodating you if you are currently enrolled at a university. They let me change from night shift to day shift so I could keep a stable sleep cycle while I went to school.

There was no crying cage or anything like it where I worked, if you had a problem, there were plenty of humans in both HR and shift leaders who were very personable if you asked them for help. But they weren't miracle workers. If the problem was Amazon related, it's probably over their pay-grade.

Actually didn't realize how much I hated that job till I sat down here to write it down. I honestly have nothing more to say that was positive about the company.
cons:
The company is extremely corporate: Orwellian sort of corporate.  All the way down to the lower ranks where it doesn't even make sense due to how far removed from corporate even our highest ranked supervisors were. 

By the books, unless it affects their checkbook. We made records at our "Fulfillment Center" by disregarding all sorts of rules, including some safety rules. Productivity above all else. 

Mandatory overtime during peak season (Holidays). Getting cross trained was impossible, even off season when they had no work. Likewise moving up the ladder wasn't realistic, as all higher positions were hired out. They don't really promote people. They say otherwise: They say alot of things. Most of the things they say are fluff if not outright lies.

That's the Orwellian part. Very dishonest, emotionally detached, robotic leadership. Very single minded to the point of being unreasonable: Even when breaking company records, increased productivity was still their only concern. That wouldn't be a problem if not for all the problems they caused in pursuit of breaking their own records. We had to dedicate a huge portion of the facility for handling damaged goods because our quality and safety standards had fallen so much during peak season. Pointing this out was taken defensively and treated as rude. We were destroying tens of thousands of dollars of product through attrition. There was no way in hell the producers were going to refund us for these damaged goods that were very clearly damaged on Amazon's end. It didn't matter, so long as we kept moving product in and out at record pace, the losses were tolerated.

Maybe they did the math and figured the increased productivity more than made up for it. I'm sure it probably did. But the safety issues that arose from it were another matter entirely.

Workers would cheat the system to meet the quotas. Remove items from the shelves to make room for the goods they were trying to stow, or literally cram it in, even breaking it to make it fit. With so many hands on the product, it was a finger pointing game to find out who done it. On the outbound side, all this cramming and missing goods made finding items a nightmare. A picker might have to deconstruct the entire shelf to extract one item, and then play tetris to get everything back into the shelf. All of this took time and hurt their quota. All of us complained about this, but no attempt to remedy it was ever taken. For over a year we delt with the same problems. It was all ignored and swept under the rug as a temporary seasonal issue. So we sucked it up.

Because goods were crammed into the shelves, items that came loose would often fall, as much as 4 stories. These falling hazards were a saftey issue, and like everything else were ignored.

review_title: This will be a bit of a different take on the hiring process
job_title: Senior Technical Account Manager in Nashville, TN
pros:
Demographic Info: 50+ Male with 20+ years of tech experience. I've been at Amazon for less than 6 months.

* The Next Steps were always clearly described. From my first contact with a Recruiter to being made an offer, I always knew where I was in the process. Obviously there were times where I didn't know if I "passed" an interview or not, but I did know when I would be contacted (with a specified number of days).

* Amazon went out of their way to make sure I and other candidates were well educated on the company, culture, and hiring process. From my first contact with a Recruiter, I was provided information on the LPs (you gotta know the LPs!), and other detailed information. I participated (with about 100+ other candidates) where I was given specific clarifications and instructions about the position and the specific LPs that interviewers were looking for. (They are practically giving you "the answers". 

* They set interviewees up for success. This was unlike anything I had experienced. Even during very technical, demanding interviews, I never felt like the interviewers were laying traps or coming up with "gotchas". If I made a statement or explanation about some topic, the interviewers would frequently dig for more details. (Hint: That's an LP!)

* I felt the interviewers had a vested interest in asking difficult, but good questions during the interview process, and making sure I was a good fit.

* I have seen many requests from potential candidates on "getting the answers" to the questions/scenarios. While I understand that mentality and did a serious amount of research on the type of questions asked, if you're just looking for the right answers, you're missing a HUGE part of the process. The technical ability is one thing, but the CULTURE is often overlooked. Do you really want to work at a company where you don't gel with the corporate culture? I sure didn't. I spoke with enough people and asked enough questions to get an excellent feel for the culture, and the type of people with whom I would be working.

* It's not a mono-culture. Prior to interviewing, I was expecting a "Yes Man" type of culture. It's not like that at all. It's actually very refreshing to hear disagreements about process, functionality, etc., and it's all based on what's right for the product, team, and ultimately the customer. It's not a "my turf" type of thing which I found exasperating at other companies.

* LPs. When I first heard about them, I'll admit I rolled my eyes and thought this was just another take on the infamous Corporate Mission Statement. I was very pleased that a bunch of these really resonated with my personal belief system. Another way to look at them is that even if you think the LPs are not effective, meaningful, or whatever, they provide a lens that allows you to know how people think about work, products, features, colleagues, customers, etc. (I personally like most of them.)
cons: I wish the hiring process would have been faster, but the sheer number of candidates that they have to interview is staggering. Amazon does a good job of weeding out people who do not have a good sense of analysis and non-technical people (at least for my role).

pros:
Good health benefits
Good sick pay for tenured employees
cons:
As a people manager I saw for years how the aggressive forced bell curve on performances made managers sideline team members as low performance even when untrue. Compensation is a joke as increases are usually less than inflation, even for the highest rated employees. Upon leaving I increased my salary by 75% for a similar role. Additionally, if you are given stock instead of a raise, this is counted twice, as years later when it vests the estimated sale value (pre 50% tax) is included as part of your compensation again and used as a reason not to increase your wage. I saw this happen many times with employees and myself. The promotion process is deeply flawed and heavily reliant on manager buy in (despite the claims it is objective), which is hard as managers change all the time. It is more a contest of which employees are more visible, with managers having to make a high pressure case or "pitch" to tenuously linked stakeholders with little context on the individual who can then essentially veto the promotion because "I haven't really seen X personally". Many people, myself included, were repeatedly asked to "just do one more project" etc to prove you are at the bar for promotion, with workload being always increased but the promotion never coming. Once a year has passed the slate is essentially wiped clean and you must reprove your worth to get the promotion. Overall the culture is very stressful and there is constant change of direction and management. This makes it hard to find support. Certain teams and individuals seem to be favoured and allowed to switch roles, define their own work, deliver what they like, get promotions, whilst others in the same org are sidelined and treated as lesser. I also found that there was a huge double standard in willingness to spend on employees who weren't of a super high level. This was even more obvious in covid, with no funds given to send employees even a bar of chocolate to say thank you when managers asked. It was not uncommon in my time for there to be essentially no budget for the team's Christmas party. In many teams managers would pay for treats themselves to stop employees feeling worthless. Very little money was given to support employees working from home. About 60 pound maximum towards a desk chair, if you stated you were experiencing back problems only. This is ironic for such a huge global company. Meanwhile dinners with more senior org members I attended cost thousands of pounds and unecessary and expensive plane travel was encouraged. 
More recently, the return to office campaign "working from here" has been almost unbelievably tone deaf. It is not competitive as an employer in the current climate, will not age well, and minimises and dismisses employees genuine needs and concerns. There is no need to force people, many of home were hired during covid and have never been to the office, to come into the office 4 days per week.
I suppose it is a well known name for the CV, and I met some wonderful people, but I would not recommend.

For picking it's basically the opposite. Personally, I enjoyed this a bit more but for other people you should know that you're going to be walking your whole shift instead which can be very tiring.

Another thing is a lot of times it felt like HR was very slow. They do have a lot of employees, and their HR department is massive compared to other places I've worked at so it's a bit understandable but it's still something you need to factor in.
